title: Qantas plane in runway scare
text:
Email a friend 
TIGHT runway management schedules at Brisbane Airport have resulted in a last minute “go around” for a Qantas jet this morning. 
Flight QF510 was about to touch down when it suddenly took off again, leaving passengers wondering what was going on. 
Airservices Australia confirmed a Solomon Airlines’ A320 was taking longer than expected to take off and was still on the runway when the Qantas 737 came into land. Bird’s eye view ... The view from the Air Traffic Control tower at Brisbane Airport. Picture: Jonathan Searle Source: News Limited 
“It was an Air Traffic Control initiated go-around in order to maintain runway separation,” said an Airservices Australia spokeswoman. 
“We thought the Solomon aircraft would have taken off before the Qantas plane came in, but it was moving slower than anticipated.” 
A passenger on the flight, Terry Carver of Sydney, said in his many years of flying he had never experienced anything like it. 
“I think I might’ve once (had a similar experience) flying into Augathella when there were kangaroos on the runway,” said Mr Carver. 
“But I’ve never had that experience at a major airport in Australia.” 
He said there was no “alarm” among passengers — just some surprise. 
“When the captain came on (the PA) he said there was an aircraft on the runway that wasn’t following instruction,” Mr Carver said. 
“He later said it was an ATC issue which might be the same thing.” Taking off ... Air Traffic Control monitor flights at Brisbane Airport. Pic: Jonathan Searle Source: News Limited 
In the past three years, Airservices Australia and Brisbane Airport have worked to reduce runway occupancy times from 46 seconds to 41 seconds. 
The reduction and other measures put in place by Airservices helped to improve the airport’s efficiency after it became notorious for delays, and placing aircraft into lengthy holding patterns. 
In August, 91.2 per cent of flights out of Brisbane Airport departed on time, and 92.8 per cent of arrivals landed within 15 minutes of schedule. 
That represented a dramatic improvement on 2012-13, when a mere 65.2 per cent of departures were on-time, and just 74.4 per cent of arrivals. 
Brisbane Airport Corporation is currently in the process of building a second parallel runway that is due for completion in 2020.
